options.title: -a
options.description:
The files listed as parameters for the w function
      or flag are created (or truncated) before any processing begins, by
      default. The -a option causes
      sed to delay opening each file until a command
      containing the related w function or flag is
      applied to a line of input.

options.title: -E
options.description:
Interpret regular expressions using POSIX extended regular expression
      syntax. The default behaviour is to use POSIX basic regular expression
      syntax.

options.title: -e command
options.description:
Append the editing commands specified by the command
      argument to the list of commands.

options.title: -f command_file
options.description:
Append the editing commands found in the file
      command_file to the list of commands. The editing
      commands should each be listed on a separate line.

options.title: -i[extension]
options.description:
Edit files in place, saving backups with the specified
      extension. If a zero length
      extension is given, no backup will be saved. It is
      not recommended to give a zero length extension when
      in place editing files, as it risks corruption or partial content in
      situations where disk space is exhausted, etc. In
      -i mode, the hold space, line numbers, and ranges
      are reset between files.

options.title: -r
options.description:
An alias for -E, for compatibility with GNU
    sed.

options.title: -n
options.description:
By default, each line of input is echoed to the standard output after all
      of the commands have been applied to it. The -n
      option suppresses this behavior.

options.title: -u
options.description:
Force output to be line buffered, printing each line as it becomes
      available. By default, output is line buffered when standard output is a
      terminal and block buffered otherwise. See
      setvbuf(3) for a more detailed
      explanation.
